title: Thursday, 27th April, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am

That too. In the meantime, Lloyds is the first one to catch my eye on the right so start there.

11:12 am
Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 69.59, up 2.18 (+3.23%), High: 70.70, Low: 69.29, Volume: 228.70m
PM11:13am

Thumbs up

BE11:13am

It's better! Much!

11:13 am
PM11:13am

Q1s here http://www.investe...1704270700144757D/

BE11:13am

Beat on net interest margins. Beat on provisions.

BE11:14am

Guidance on the former goes up.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

RBC can summarise where we are.

BE11:14am

LLOY results beat on NII and provisions, and the rest of the results were in line. Guidance was upgraded on NIM, cost of risk and capital generation, which should be received well by the market. We rate LLOY Outperform, 90p price target, currently trading at 1.19x latest TBV and targeting a 13.5-15% ROTE in 2019.

BE11:14am

NII increased 1%yoy, 3% beat versus consensus. The banking NIM in the quarter increased to 2.8% from 2.68% in Q4. LLOY upgraded the guidance on NIM from greater than 2.7% to "close to 2.8%" (all excluding the impact of MBNA). This compares to consensus of 2.75% for 2017- all else equal, the guidance versus consensus is worth c.£215m on consensus numbers of 3% to consensus PBT estimates. Offsetting this positive development in results is a 1.6% contraction in average interest-earning assets, but LLOY expects open-book mortgages to stabilise and to end the year in line with 2016- consensus has flat AIEAs in 2017 versus 2016 already.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Fees were flat yoy, 1% below consensus but in line with our estimate. Consumer finance fees saw growth; insurance income was stable; and retail and commercial banking fees were lower year on year. Total revenues beat consensus by 1%.

BE11:15am

Total costs increased 1%yoy, in line with consensus (operating costs fell 1%yoy) LLOY remains on track to meet its cost guidance and maintains the 2019 target of 45% cost/income ratio exiting 2019 with reductions each year.

BE11:15am

If time travelled back to 2009 and told people that within less than a decade you'd be paying 1.2 times book for Lloyds and 0.8 times for StanChart .......

11:15 am
BE11:16am

....... then you'd be wasting your power of time travel.

PM11:16am

hehehe

BE11:16am

Ian Gordon's keen. Investec.

11:16 am
PM11:16am

Trader Gordon is ecstatic!

BE11:16am

Lloyds’ investors are waking up to a (pretty glorious) reality...the Q1 IMS has delivered a consensus beat on NIM (2.80% vs 2.70%), costs (at £2.0bn, a £6m beat), impairments (£127m (12bps) – a 48% beat) and CET1 capital (14.3% vs 13.8%). In aggregate, underlying PBT (£2.1bn) is 4% ahead of us (£2.0bn) and 10% ahead of company-compiled consensus (£1.9bn). As discussed in our report, Sellside humiliation is not yet complete, (24 April), further material impairment/NIM/DPS-led consensus upgrades seem inevitable. BUY.

BE11:17am

CET1 capital rises 50bps to 14.3%. Consensus inexplicably forecast £1.0bn of retained earnings yet had no CET1 growth. FY17 capital accretion guidance is raised to the “top end” of the 170-200bps range. We expect DPS forecasts to rise. We already forecast 4.5p in 2017e vs consensus (so far) up to 3.8p.

On 1.2x 2016 tNAV, Buy recommendation and 74p TP reaffirmed. Only the finer detail of our forecasts is now under review.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Just searching though the others and they all say pretty much that.

BE11:18am

Strong quarter with 1Q op profit of £2.08bn, c.10% ahead of consensus, improved guidance for NIM close to 2.80% and impairment below 25bps (pre-MBNA) indicates mid-single digit upside to consensus EPS, capital return story to accelerate and stock looks cheap at 9.0x 2018e EPS vs sector on 11.1x.

BE11:18am

That's Morgan Stanley, and is succinct enough to close this section I feel.

11:18 am
undefined
BE11:19am

Stepping away from trading updates for a moment ...........

PM11:19am

sure

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Lots of folk talking about Diageo this morning

Diageo PLC (DGE:LSE): Last: 2,239, down 22.5 (-1.00%), High: 2,260, Low: 2,233, Volume: 887.00k
BE11:20am

On the back of some fantasy M&A from Exane.

11:20 am
PM11:20am

After LVMH i presume

BE11:20am

Not specifically, and it's more reverse fantasy M&A.

BE11:21am

It's a teardown of 3G and ABI, albeit with nothing expected to happen any time soon.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Here's why 3G might want Diageo.

BE11:21am

If world domination in the 'dull' staples industry is 3G's aim, Diageo has clear appeal. It operates in an industry with arguably the best growth days ahead, with high barriers of entry in places, Diageo has some fantastic brands positions, there are opportunities on costs cash, and there is scarcity value (Diageo is probably the only large spirits M&A option available).

BE11:21am

And here's why it might not: it's expensive!

11:21 am
BE11:22am

While we see logic in 3G acquiring Diageo, thereby creating a 'Spirits House', we struggle with the maths. More than $50bn of equity would likely be needed: an amount of money which is not easy to come by and even so, LBO returns would likely underwhelm.

PM11:22am

How about the fact that it would/should be blocked by the competition authorities???

BE11:22am

I'm not sure why it would. Beer and vodka are not really interchangeable.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

Well, I guess they are ...... but perhaps not to an antitrust officer.

BE11:23am

The Exane thesis says ABI is the more likely buyer.

BE11:23am

ABInBev acquiring Diageo makes more sense to us (Guinness Africa, synergies, $100bn sales 'target'), and if plan A (Coca-Cola) or arguably plan B (Pepsi) are not pulled off, we see a very good chance that ABInBev casts its eyes towards the global spirits leader. This said, any such move is likely to be years away given current leverage priorities at the global beer leader.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

... but no time soon.

BE11:23am

We think Diageo can sleep easy for now. Management have time to realise the group's significant growth potential. We back them to do this (Giants awakening, No longer on the rocks), but if we are wrong, others may well seek to fulfil Diageo's potential in the future. The distiller cannot rest on its laurels. Outperform maintained.

PM11:23am

Actually I think I'm confused and confusing this.

11:23 am
PM11:23am

Ignore me

BE11:24am

OK! Have a chart.

BE11:24am

11:24 am
PM11:25am

(Watch i Flaneur. Seriously.)

BE11:25am

So you're looking at Inbeviageo having 15% spirits, 85% beer.

BE11:26am

11:26 am
PM11:26am

BE11:27am

BE11:27am

BE11:28am

BE11:29am

Yes! I've been boring in here in the past about Sorghum, the hooch-like liquor that tastes of stewed death.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

And SABMiller as was, with its attempts to get customers to drink beer that tastes slightly less like stewed death, but having trouble finding the cost-taste differential.

BE11:30am

Anyway, I'll stop with that. But it's interesting stuff.

So, not being an expert in Middle East healthcare structures, I spent several minutes this morning tracking down a JPM Cazenove upgrade in response to the news.

11:33 am

Mediclinic International PLC (MDC:LSE): Last: 859.50, up 128.5 (+17.58%), High: 888.00, Low: 741.00, Volume: 2.58m
BE11:34am

.... I guess JPM's previous research on the theme was longer.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Jefferies, thankfully, has put some meat on the bone.

BE11:34am

The cancellation of the 20% co-pay for Thiqa patients is positive for the UAE hospital sector, which has acted as a drag since it was introduced in 2H 2016. Although we expect little near term benefit, it adds support to the LT investment case so we expect a near-term positive share price reaction on sentiment ahead of more details being disclosed.

BE11:35am

What happened? The UAE National reports today that Sheikh Mohammed has cancelled the 20% co-pay on private treatment for Thiqa holders; at the same time he has ordered a specialist medical college and a healthcare city to be established to strengthen the emirate as a destination for medical tourism and services. This follows the January announcement that the co-pay for long-term care would be scrapped, which benefited NMC. We await further details if other limits will be removed, such as the limitations of one cycle of IVF per year and the co-pay for private healthcare treatment outside of Abu Dhabi, but it nevertheless illustrates the leadership’s support for private health.

11:34 am
BE11:35am

Limited near-term upside for NMC (Buy) but raises LT prospects: We do not expect NMC to raise its $335-$350m EBITDA guidance for 2017E as we believe near-term upside is limited. However, if the co-pay is removed for treatment outside of Abu Dhabi (which is c.50%), we would view this more positively for NMC; similarly NMC has a sizeable IVF business so would benefit from the removal of the cap on treatment. We believe the news today is supportive in particular to the ramp-up of NMC Royal where the expectations are it will treat more Thiqa patients.

BE11:35am

Relief provides much-needed support for Mediclinic (Underperform) but challenges remain: In our view, Mediclinic had greater exposure to this reform given a greater focus on Thiqa patients, so it should see a greater benefit, but we await details as to the expected impact at its FY Results on 24 May. We still expect FY2018 to be a turnaround year given: 1) current doctor vacancies still need to be filled; 2) it takes time for newly hired doctors to build a book of business; and 3) there are risks associated with rebranding all Al Noor hospitals as Mediclinic as its brand is not so well-known in Abu Dhabi. We therefore would caution extrapolating too much upside near-term, but sentiment should improve following this development.

NMC Health PLC (NMC:LSE): Last: 1,947, up 34 (+1.78%), High: 1,967, Low: 1,918, Volume: 82.46k
11:36 am
BE11:36am

One also wonders whether 20% on Mediclinic increases the chances of it doing the long-rumoured deal to take out Spire.

Spire Healthcare Group PLC (SPI:LSE): Last: 329.60, up 8 (+2.49%), High: 329.90, Low: 323.20, Volume: 236.28k
PM11:36am

11:36 am
BE11:36am

@bilandor: we've no idea why Atkins is trading through the terms.

BE11:38am

They'll probably make some noise about SNC paying more, as they do because they're Elliott, but they're in a no-lose position.

PM11:39am

You don't like Elliott, do you Bryce?

11:39 am

BE11:41am

I'm not against activists as a whole. But if you want to get aggro on live M&A, you should be doing it with a genuine intention to break a deal that you think is value destructive.

BE11:41am

All Elliott does is try and make deals more value destructive.

11:41 am

BE11:41am

11:43 am

PM11:43am

PM11:43am

http://www.investe...170427070100P455E/

11:43 am
Fidessa Group PLC (FDSA:LSE): Last: 2,382, down 229 (-8.77%), High: 2,583, Low: 2,374, Volume: 30.35k
BE11:44am

Not suer why the shares had a run up pre results. FX maybe.

BE11:44am

Here's Numis, which downgrades from buy.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Fidessa's Q1 IMS is largely consistent with the FY16 outlook statement, but extends the slight note of geopolitical caution from that statement (Brexit, European elections and the new US administration). In particular, the statement notes that during Q1, some customers took longer than normal to make decisions. Despite this, management believe that constant currency revenue growth for the year will be consistent with previous guidance, i.e. at similar levels to 2016. Currency tailwinds remain although volatility in recent days means that if current rates persist, we are probably closer to a 3.5% revenue benefit than the 4.5% we model. We think risk is modestly elevated here; if the Q1 softness were to develop further, we think FY17 and beyond could see slight (c.1-2%) reductions in growth rates. We note that were this to come to pass, it would simply return forecasts to where they were at the start of the year, following our post-FY16 upgrades. Valuation unchanged, as is the investment case - Fidessa is creating considerable value in its derivatives business in our view, and the market continues not to recognise this in the overall valuation. Ex-derivatives at £150m, equities trades on c.15x CY17 EV:NOPAT. The strong performance of the shares in recent months means our recommendation moves to Add.

undefined
BE11:50am

And since we're not doing DPL, we'll not do it about Taylor Wimpey too.

11:50 am
Taylor Wimpey PLC (TW.:LSE): Last: 200.10, up 1.6 (+0.81%), High: 201.50, Low: 195.90, Volume: 9.69m
BE11:51am

Which has set aside £130m to refund buyers it tried to rip off on ground rents.

BE11:52am

This was on flats sold between 2007 and 2011 up north, where ground rent doubled shortly after purchase.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Hey, here's a thought. How about reform of ground rent law?

BE11:53am

The ground rent + tied service charge scam is an under-recognised problem, because it's suffered mostly by poor people.

BE11:53am

As in, owners of ex council houses.

11:53 am
BE11:54am

So it gets no press whatsoever, and it's an absolute racket.

PM11:54am

I didn't know about this.

BE11:54am

Anyway, TW's doing the right thing and compensating those it ripped off while still bleating on about having done nothing illegal.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

We acknowledge that the introduction of these doubling clauses was not consistent with our high standards of customer service and we are sorry for the unintended financial consequence and concern that they are causing.

BE11:54am

For those customers who acquired from, and remain the owner of a Taylor Wimpey leasehold property which is subject to this specific doubling clause, we have already entered into negotiations with the respective owners of the majority of the freeholds to alter the terms of the doubling lease to materially less expensive ground rent review terms, with the group bearing the financial cost of doing so.

BE11:55am

In the event that we are not able to reach agreement with individual freeholders, we will continue to pursue other avenues to help our customers.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

The clause in the TW contract was for ground rent to double every ten years, if I remember correctly.

BE11:56am

(@wayneJ: ground rent on my very cheap ex-council flat used to be owned by a Tchenguiz, if that answers your question.)

BE11:57am

Anyway, it's all good news for shareholders. Or at least not outright negative. Here's UBS.

11:56 am
BE11:57am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: Sales rates are robust at +16% y/y to 0.93 sales per site per week (PY: 0.80), which implies +14% y/y growth since last reporting in February.

BE11:57am

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: TW will book a £130m provision to compensate lease holders for ground rents on developments on some developments which started between 2007-11. While the terms were legal, the group wants to rectify any customer satisfaction issues. Net of tax the cash impact will be slightly over £100m, c3% of NAV and 1.6% of the market cap.

BE11:57am

Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: No. Company feels comfortable with consensus ASP growth of +3.5% and volume growth of +4%. We expect average consensus PBT of £789m to slightly rise towards our estimate of £814m.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: Slightly negative. The ground rent issue was partly expected and the group is sticking to its dividend commitment and trading is robust.
